metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: identify that all electromagnetic waves travel at the same speed, c, in a vacuum

em_wave_production.name: EM Wave Production
em_wave_production.correct: Electromagnetic waves are produced by accelerating charged particles, which create changing electric fields that generate changing magnetic fields.

stationary charges.error: Stationary charges create static fields, not waves.
stationary charges.fix: Only accelerating charges produce the changing fields needed for EM waves.
stationary charges.action: Compare: stationary charge creates constant E field. Oscillating charge creates oscillating E and B fields.

moving at constant velocity.error: Constant velocity means no acceleration, so no EM waves.
moving at constant velocity.fix: The charge must be accelerating to produce changing fields.
moving at constant velocity.action: Recall Newton: a = dv/dt. Constant v means a = 0.

magnetic fields only.error: Both electric AND magnetic fields are required.
magnetic fields only.fix: A changing E field creates a changing B field, and vice versa.
magnetic fields only.action: EM waves have perpendicular E and B fields that sustain each other.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how EM waves are generated.
persistent.action: Review Maxwell's equations conceptually: changing E creates B, changing B creates E.

em_wave_structure.name: EM Wave Structure
em_wave_structure.correct: In an electromagnetic wave, the electric and magnetic fields oscillate perpendicular to each other AND perpendicular to the direction of wave travel.

parallel to each other.error: E and B fields are perpendicular, not parallel.
parallel to each other.fix: The fields are at 90 degrees to each other.
parallel to each other.action: Visualise: E oscillates vertically, B oscillates horizontally, wave travels forward.

parallel to direction of travel.error: That would be a longitudinal wave. EM waves are transverse.
parallel to direction of travel.fix: Both fields oscillate perpendicular to wave direction.
parallel to direction of travel.action: Sound waves are longitudinal. Light waves are transverse.

only electric field oscillates.error: Both E and B fields oscillate together.
only electric field oscillates.fix: The two fields are linked and both must be present.
only electric field oscillates.action: A changing E creates a changing B. They cannot exist alone in a wave.

persistent.gap: You are confusing longitudinal and transverse waves.
persistent.action: Draw an EM wave: show E, B, and direction of travel all perpendicular to each other.

transverse_wave.name: Transverse Wave Nature
transverse_wave.correct: Electromagnetic waves are transverse waves because the oscillating fields are perpendicular to the direction of energy propagation.

longitudinal.error: Longitudinal means oscillation parallel to travel. EM waves are transverse.
longitudinal.fix: Sound is longitudinal. Light is transverse.
longitudinal.action: In transverse waves, shake a rope side-to-side while the wave travels along it.

mechanical.error: Mechanical waves need a medium. EM waves do not.
mechanical.fix: EM waves are not mechanical. They propagate through electric and magnetic fields.
mechanical.action: Light travels through vacuum. Sound cannot.

surface.error: Surface waves occur at interfaces. EM waves travel through space.
surface.fix: EM waves do not require any material boundary.
surface.action: Surface waves need water/air boundary. EM waves need nothing.

persistent.action: Make a table: mechanical vs EM, transverse vs longitudinal. List examples of each.

speed_of_light_value.name: Speed of Light Value
speed_of_light_value.correct: The speed of light in a vacuum is exactly 299,792,458 m/s, commonly rounded to 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s.

3.0 × 10⁶ m/s.error: Wrong exponent. Off by a factor of 100.
3.0 × 10⁶ m/s.fix: c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. The exponent is 8, not 6.
3.0 × 10⁶ m/s.action: Light travels about 300 million metres per second.

3.0 × 10¹⁰ m/s.error: Wrong exponent. Too fast by a factor of 100.
3.0 × 10¹⁰ m/s.fix: c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s. The exponent is 8, not 10.

340 m/s.error: That is the speed of sound in air, not light.
340 m/s.fix: Sound is about 340 m/s. Light is 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s.
340 m/s.action: Light is about a million times faster than sound.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise the speed of light.
persistent.action: Flashcard: c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s = 300,000 km/s. Review daily.

all_em_same_speed.name: Universal Speed in Vacuum
all_em_same_speed.formula: All EM waves travel at c in vacuum
all_em_same_speed.correct: All electromagnetic waves, regardless of frequency or wavelength, travel at exactly the same speed c in a vacuum.

higher frequency travels faster.error: Frequency does not affect speed in vacuum.
higher frequency travels faster.fix: In vacuum, c = fλ means if f increases, λ decreases. Speed stays constant.
higher frequency travels faster.action: Radio waves and gamma rays both travel at c in vacuum.

shorter wavelength travels faster.error: Wavelength does not affect speed in vacuum.
shorter wavelength travels faster.fix: All EM waves have the same speed c in vacuum, regardless of wavelength.
shorter wavelength travels faster.action: Red light and blue light travel at the same speed in vacuum.

visible light travels fastest.error: No type of EM wave is faster than another in vacuum.
visible light travels fastest.fix: Radio, microwave, IR, visible, UV, X-ray, gamma. All travel at c.
visible light travels fastest.action: The entire EM spectrum shares the same vacuum speed.

persistent.gap: You think different EM waves have different speeds in vacuum.
persistent.action: Key concept: In vacuum, speed is constant. c = fλ means f and λ are inversely related.

wave_equation.name: Wave Equation
wave_equation.correct: The wave equation c = fλ relates the speed of light to frequency and wavelength, where increasing frequency means decreasing wavelength at constant speed.

c = f/λ.error: Division is wrong. It is multiplication.
c = f/λ.fix: c = f × λ. Frequency times wavelength equals speed.
c = f/λ.action: Check units: Hz × m = (1/s) × m = m/s. Correct.

c = λ/f.error: Inverted. Speed equals frequency times wavelength.
c = λ/f.action: Rearrange: λ = c/f and f = c/λ. But c = fλ.

f = cλ.error: That gives wrong units and wrong relationship.
f = cλ.action: Check: c/λ = (m/s)/(m) = 1/s = Hz. Correct units for frequency.

persistent.gap: You are confusing the wave equation.
persistent.action: Memorise: c = fλ. Speed = frequency × wavelength. Practice rearranging.

frequency_wavelength_inverse.name: Frequency-Wavelength Relationship
frequency_wavelength_inverse.correct: At constant speed c, frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional: higher frequency means shorter wavelength.

directly proportional.fix: From c = fλ: if f doubles, λ halves.
directly proportional.action: Think: product fλ must equal constant c. If one goes up, other goes down.

independent of each other.error: They are mathematically linked by c = fλ.
independent of each other.fix: Frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional at constant speed.
independent of each other.action: Calculate: 600 nm light has f = c/λ. 300 nm light has double the frequency.

both increase together.error: If both increased, c = fλ would increase. But c is constant.
both increase together.fix: Speed is fixed in vacuum. One must decrease if the other increases.
both increase together.action: Product fλ = c is constant. So f↑ means λ↓.

persistent.gap: You do not understand inverse proportionality.
persistent.action: Calculate f and λ for several EM waves. Verify fλ always equals 3 × 10⁸.

em_spectrum_regions.name: EM Spectrum Regions
em_spectrum_regions.formula: Radio → Microwave → IR → Visible → UV → X-ray → Gamma
em_spectrum_regions.correct: The electromagnetic spectrum ranges from low-frequency radio waves to high-frequency gamma rays, all travelling at c in vacuum.

only visible light is electromagnetic.fix: Radio, microwave, IR, visible, UV, X-ray, gamma are all EM waves.
only visible light is electromagnetic.action: Visible light is just the small portion our eyes detect.

radio waves are not light.error: Radio waves ARE electromagnetic radiation, same as light.
radio waves are not light.fix: All EM waves are fundamentally the same phenomenon at different frequencies.
radio waves are not light.action: Radio and gamma rays both obey c = fλ in vacuum.

gamma rays are fastest.error: All EM waves travel at the same speed in vacuum.
gamma rays are fastest.fix: Gamma rays have highest frequency, not highest speed.
gamma rays are fastest.action: Higher frequency means more energy per photon, not faster travel.

persistent.gap: You do not see the EM spectrum as unified.
persistent.action: Draw the full spectrum with frequency increasing left to right. All at same speed c.

no_medium_required.name: No Medium Required
no_medium_required.correct: Electromagnetic waves do not require a medium to travel. They propagate through the self-sustaining oscillation of electric and magnetic fields.

need air to travel.error: Air is not required. EM waves travel through vacuum.
need air to travel.fix: Light from the Sun travels through empty space to reach Earth.
need air to travel.action: Space is a vacuum. Sunlight still reaches us.

need ether.error: The ether was disproved by Michelson-Morley experiment.
need ether.fix: There is no medium. EM waves are self-propagating field oscillations.
need ether.action: Historical note: Einstein's relativity eliminated the need for ether.

travel faster through matter.error: EM waves travel SLOWER through matter than through vacuum.
travel faster through matter.fix: Speed in vacuum (c) is the maximum. In materials, v = c/n where n > 1.
travel faster through matter.action: Refractive index n > 1 means light slows down in materials.

persistent.gap: You think EM waves need a medium like sound does.
persistent.action: Key difference: sound is mechanical (needs matter), light is electromagnetic (needs nothing).

speed_in_media.name: Speed in Media
speed_in_media.correct: In materials, EM waves travel slower than in vacuum. The speed is v = c/n, where n is the refractive index (always greater than 1 for materials).

same speed in all materials.error: Speed depends on the material through refractive index.
same speed in all materials.fix: v = c/n. Different materials have different n values.
same speed in all materials.action: Light slows in glass (n ≈ 1.5) more than in water (n ≈ 1.33).

faster in denser materials.error: Generally, denser materials have higher n, so light goes slower.
faster in denser materials.fix: Higher n means slower light: v = c/n.
faster in denser materials.action: Compare: air (n ≈ 1), water (n ≈ 1.33), glass (n ≈ 1.5). Light slows as n increases.

speed varies with frequency in vacuum.error: In VACUUM, speed is always c regardless of frequency.
speed varies with frequency in vacuum.fix: Speed varies with frequency only in some materials (dispersion), not in vacuum.
speed varies with frequency in vacuum.action: Vacuum is special: all EM waves travel at exactly c.

persistent.gap: You confuse vacuum speed with speed in materials.
persistent.action: Distinguish: In vacuum, always c. In materials, v = c/n < c.

historical_measurement.name: Historical Speed Measurement
historical_measurement.correct: Ole Rømer first measured the finite speed of light in 1676 by observing timing variations in the eclipses of Jupiter's moon Io as Earth's distance from Jupiter changed.

measured directly in a lab.error: Rømer used astronomical observations, not laboratory equipment.
measured directly in a lab.fix: The first measurement used the orbital timing of Io around Jupiter.
measured directly in a lab.action: When Earth is farther from Jupiter, light takes longer to reach us.

proved light travels instantaneously.error: Rømer proved light has finite speed, not infinite.
proved light travels instantaneously.fix: The time delay showed light takes time to travel.
proved light travels instantaneously.action: About 22 minutes (now known to be 16.7 min) to cross Earth's orbit diameter.

used the Michelson-Morley experiment.error: Michelson-Morley tested for ether, not the speed of light.

persistent.gap: You do not know the history of light speed measurement.
persistent.action: Timeline: Rømer (1676) proved finite speed. Later lab measurements refined the value.
